description: The endangered kea is the world's only alpine parrot, and one of the most intelligent birds. The kea has been crowned Bird of the Year for 2017.
Known for its friendly 'cheet cheet' call and energetic flying antics, the aptly named fantail is one of the most common and widely distributed native birds on the New Zealand mainland.
Blackbirds are commonly seen feeding on the ground in parklands, woodlands and suburban gardens, walking slowly or running short distances looking for food.
The kaka is a large parrot belonging to the nestorinae family, a group that includes the kea and the extinct Norfolk Island kaka.
Kakariki, meaning 'small green parrot' in Maori, are beautiful forest birds. They feed on berries, seeds, fruit and insects, and generally nest in holes in trees.
Pigeons is a common urban dwelling bird that are not shy when scavenging the ground for food scraps.
The pukeko is probably one of the most recognised native birds in New Zealand with its distinctive colourings and habit of feeding on the ground.
The seagull is a common large bird found on many beaches, landfills, around ports and at fish-processing plants.
House sparrows are small birds found commonly everywhere.
The silvereye - also known as the wax-eye, or sometimes white eye - is a small and friendly olive green forest bird with white rings around its eyes.
The kereru is a large bird with irridescent green and bronze feathers on its head and a smart white vest. The noisy beat of its wings is a distinctive sound in our forests.
Tui are unique to New Zealand and belong to the honeyeater family, which means they feed mainly on nectar from flowers of native plants.
